{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7400,"attracts":[],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"water parsnip","description":"Water parsnip (Sium suave) is a robust plant native to wetland regions. It has stout stems and produces large white flowers. The plant grows to 1-2.5 m in height. Its leaves are long and pinnately divided into leaflets, each with toothed margins. Its seed heads are flat and outward pointing which gives the plant a distinctive look with yellowish-green, star-shaped flowers. The water parsnip grows in shallow ponds and other areas with seasonal flooding, and its roots nicely filter out unwanted materials from the water. Overall, it is a striking and elegant plant that adds great decorative value to wetland areas.","family":"Apiaceae","flower_color":"White","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":[],"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["green","yellow","purple"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Cutting","Seed Propagation","Layering Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March","April"],"scientific_name":["Sium suave"],"soil":[],"watering_period":null}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7403,"attracts":[],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"nightshade","description":"Nightshade (Solanum crispum) is a shrubby, perennial plant found in temperate regions around the world. It has small, white flowers and edible purple or black berries. Its leaves are alternate and are armed with needle-like spines. All forms of Solanum crispum contain toxic compounds which can cause illness, so the leaves and berries should not be eaten. Despite the health warnings, nightshade is still used as a medicinal plant in some countries due to its purported ability to treat a variety of ailments. It is commonly grown in cultivated gardens as an ornamental or even for a food source for local wildlife. Its unusual blooms will brighten up any garden.","family":"Solanaceae","flower_color":"Dark blue with yellow stamens","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":[],"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Fall","leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Chile"," Argentina"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Layering Propagation","Grafting Propagation","Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March","April"],"scientific_name":["Solanum crispum"],"soil":[],"watering_period":"Night"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7406,"attracts":[],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"eggplant","description":"Eggplant (Solanum melongena 'Aswad') is a variety of eggplant originating from the Middle East. It is a flowering herbaceous perennial, featuring broad, deep purple-black fruit with white flesh. This cultivar grows to approximately 1-2 feet tall, preferring sunny or partially shaded locations. Unripe fruits may be harvested in 85 to 90 days. Fruits are best picked when they are 8 to 10 inches in length and the skin is matte and not shiny. Eggplants have a bold flavor that is mild and slightly smoky. Eggplant 'Aswad' is a great addition to any garden and can be eaten raw, cooked, or used in salads.","family":"Solanaceae","flower_color":"Violet","flowering_season":"Spring","fruit_color":[],"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Sri Lanka"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":["Mites"," Root rot"," Thrips"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March","April","May","June","July","August","September","March","April","May","June","July","August","September","August","May"],"scientific_name":["Solanum melongena 'Aswad'"],"soil":[],"watering_period":null}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7409,"attracts":[],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"potato","description":"The potato, scientifically known as Solanum tuberosum, is a perennially growing crop with an annual life cycle. It has a starchy, tuberous root that stores nutrients, and its stem and leaves are characterized by large, lobed leaves with white, purple or pink flowers. They can range in color from cream, to pink, to yellow, and are commonly eaten boiled, baked, roasted, or fried. Potatoes are an important source of carbohydrates and are also a great source of dietary fiber, vitamin C, and potassium. They contain no fat, cholesterol, or sodium and provide a good source of iron and magnesium as well as several other minerals.","family":"Solanaceae","flower_color":"Showy, White, Blue, Pink, Purple","flowering_season":"Summer","fruit_color":["green","yellow","white"],"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Fall","leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":["Rabbit resistant"],"propagation":["Cutting","Tuber Division","Grafting Propagation","Tissue Culture","Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Solanum tuberosum"],"soil":[],"watering_period":null}}

Old field goldenrod is hardy in USDA Zones 4-8 and thrives in full sun to partial shade and well-drained soils. It can tolerate dry soils and is drought-tolerant once established. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7440,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bog goldenrod","description":"Bog Goldenrod (Solidago uliginosa) is a perennial plant found in wetland habitats throughout North America. Its erect stems are up to five feet tall, bearing softly hairy, golden-yellow clusters of flowers in late summer and autumn. The leaves are long, narrow, and grass-like. Its slick, black rootstock is rhizomatous and propagates from seed or underground stem buds. The plant will die back in the winter and reappear in spring. Bog Goldenrod provides nectar sources for butterflies, moths, and other beneficial insects, as well as a larval host plant for many species of butterflies. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7505,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":null,"common_name":"spirea","description":"Spirea (Spiraea thunbergii) is an attractive, deciduous flowering shrub with arching branches and white flowers. Native to Japan, this showy shrub is commonly used as a hedge or in perennial borders. Growing 3-5 feet tall, this shrub produces flashing white flowers in the spring, making it a sure standout in the garden. With good drainage and a full sun location, Spirea can be easily maintained year round. Blooming in late spring, the blooms can be cut back in late May to encourage a repeat bloom in the summer. It's foliage changes color with the seasons, beginning with a reddish hue in the spring and then a bright green in the summer. Spirea thunbergii's height and arching branches make it an ideal backdrop for other flowering plants and its showy flowers add bright detail to any garden.","family":"Rosaceae","flower_color":"White","flowering_season":"Spring","fruit_color":["yellow","white"],"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Fall","leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["China"," Japan"],"other_name":["baby's breath spirea"],"pest_susceptibility":["Pest resistant"," Disease resistant"," Deer resistant"," Drought resistant"],"propagation":["Greenwood Cuttings"],"pruning_month":["March","April"],"scientific_name":["Spiraea thunbergii"],"soil":["Humus rich"," Well-drained"],"watering_period":"morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7526,"attracts":[],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"big betony","description":"Big Betony is a species of plant belonging to the mint family. It has a short stem and opposite, pubescent leaves that tend to be kidney-shaped. Its flower spikes are a stunning shade of violet and feature larger flowers at the base of the spike with smaller flowers as you move downward. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7573,"attracts":[],"care_level":"High","common_name":"jade vine","description":"Jade Vine (Strongylodon macrobotrys) is an exotic climbing plant native to the rainforests of the Philippines. It has long, elegant stems, with glossy heart-shaped leaves that grow in mid-green clusters along the vine. In spring, the plant produces spectacular clusters of bright blue-green, trumpet-shaped flowers, which hang from the stems in bunches. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7410,"attracts":[],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"baby's tears","description":"Baby's Tears (Soleirolia soleirolii) is a lush, low-growing mat-forming plant originating from the Mediterranean regions. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7426,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":"Moderate","common_name":"old field goldenrod","description":"Old field goldenrod (Solidago nemoralis) is a small clumping perennial native to North America. It has thin, lance-shaped leaves and large yellow or golden-orange flower spikes that bloom from August to October. The flowers are highly attractive to bees, butterflies, and other pollinators. Old field goldenrod is hardy in USDA Zones 4-8 and thrives in full sun to partial shade and well-drained soils. It can tolerate dry soils and is drought-tolerant once established. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7438,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":null,"common_name":"goldenrod","description":"A beautiful late season perennial, goldenrod (Solidago sphacelata 'Golden Fleece') is a must-have for any garden! Its erect stems are up to five feet tall, bearing softly hairy, golden-yellow clusters of flowers in late summer and autumn. The leaves are long, narrow, and grass-like. Its slick, black rootstock is rhizomatous and propagates from seed or underground stem buds. The plant will die back in the winter and reappear in spring. Bog Goldenrod provides nectar sources for butterflies, moths, and other beneficial insects, as well as a larval host plant for many species of butterflies. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7523,"attracts":[],"care_level":"Low","common_name":"lamb's ears","description":"Lamb's ears (Stachys byzantina 'Silver Carpet') is an easy to grow evergreen perennial that grows in a lush, low-growing mat of soft, fuzzy, silvery-green foliage. This variety of Stachys is known for its soft, velvety texture and interesting form. The tiny, star-shaped, lavender-hued flowers appear in late spring and summer. This perennial grows upright to around 18-48 inches tall and is topped with cylindrical clusters of star-shaped blooms. This plant thrives in dry, sandy soil with plenty of sun and can tolerate drought once established. Its foliage is fine and feathery, creating a beautiful backdrop for the showy flowers. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7597,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"heath aster","description":"Heath Aster (Symphyotrichum ericoides 'Snow Flurry') is a showy perennial aster, providing a long season of bloom in the garden. Finely-textured foliage provides deep green coloration, and bright white flowers appear in late summer and fall. The Snow Flurry variety of heath aster will create a cloud-like appearance, with small white aster blossoms standing out against the green foliage. It can be planted in a grouping with other perennials, or as a stand-alone specimen in a sunny or partly-shaded area. Heath aster is an easy-care plant, requiring only moderate water and regular fertilization.","family":"Asteraceae","flower_color":"White with yellow centers","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":[],"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["silver","green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Canada","United States"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Cutting","Seed Propagation","Layering Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May","November","March","April"],"scientific_name":["Symphyotrichum ericoides 'Snow Flurry'"],"soil":[],"watering_period":null}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7596,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"heath aster","description":"Heath Aster is a beautiful and adaptable perennial plant native to North America. It's characterized by its bright blue star-shaped flowers and lacy grey-green leaves. Reaching heights of around 2 feet, this compact plant adds a delicate texture and warm touch of color to any garden. Deadheading will keep the plants blooming throughout the summer months and cut back in fall to promote healthy growth in the spring. Heath Asters are hardy to USDA Hardiness Zones 3-8 and are easy to grow in sun to partial shade.","family":"Asteraceae","flower_color":"Powdery blue rays and yellow center disks","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":[],"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["silver","green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Canada","United States"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Cutting","Seed Propagation","Layering Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February","March","April","February"],"scientific_name":["Symphyotrichum ericoides 'Blue Star'"],"soil":[],"watering_period":null}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7599,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"smooth aster","description":"Smooth aster (Symphyotrichum laeve 'Bluebird') is a perennial flower native to North America. It grows between two to three feet tall, and features daisy-like flowers of deep purple, pink, or white blooms on thin stems. The ray flowers are exceptionally delicate with smooth, fringed tips, and the center of the flower is composed of tightly packed yellow disc florets. The evergreen foliage has a glossy sheen and is shades of grey-green. Smooth aster is tolerant of a wide range of soil types, and prefers full sun or partial shade. It is an excellent choice to provide late season color to garden beds and container gardens.","family":"Asteraceae","flower_color":"Violet blue rays with yellow center","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":[],"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Cutting","Layering Propagation","Seed Propagation","Grafting Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February","March","April","March","April","May"],"scientific_name":["Symphyotrichum laeve 'Bluebird'"],"soil":[],"watering_period":"morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7598,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":null,"common_name":"smooth aster","description":"Smooth Aster (Symphyotrichum laeve), also known as Blue Wild Indigo, is a perennial herb with an upright or sprawling habit. Its striking lavender colored flowers appear from July to October and have yellow centers. The smooth, lance-shaped leaves are arranged in an alternate pattern on the stem. It is a hardy, adaptable plant that does well in many soil types and is drought-resistant. It is easy to grow in sunny to partially shaded locations and provides excellent late season color for gardens and meadows. The flowers are attractive to beneficial insects and butterflies, making them an ideal inclusion in pollinator-friendly gardens.","family":"Asteraceae","flower_color":"Violet to purple rays and yellow centers","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":[],"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North American"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting","Division","Layering Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February","March","April"],"scientific_name":["Symphyotrichum laeve"],"soil":["Sandy Loamy Rocky"],"watering_period":null}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7600,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"white woodland aster","description":"The white woodland aster (Symphyotrichum lateriflorum) is a blooming perennial plant with tiny white flowers. This plant grows to be 2 to 4 feet tall and can be found in woodlands or meadows. It grows best in moist, well-drained soil and prefers full to partial sun. It blooms in late summer and can bring colour to garden areas. It’s a great choice for a wildlife garden, to attract butterflies and other insects. This plant is also a great source of nectar for pollinators. With its small and delicate flowers, it may look fragile, but this species is actually quite hardy.","family":"Asteraceae","flower_color":"White with reddish-purple centers","flowering_season":"Autumn","fruit_color":["brown"],"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Fall","leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"," Mites"," Mold"," Nematodes"," Rust"," Slugs","snails","  Rabbit resistant "],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February","March","April"],"scientific_name":["Symphyotrichum lateriflorum"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":null}}
